content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: So original and interesting

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Quite original!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good one !

I found issues while testing your Clash in PHP. The base conversion from Test base 4 and the tests after, we don't have the same result. I think it is due once again to the limit restrictions for big  numbers in the php.ini... (if one day CodinGame could resolve this problem...)

Anyway ! For the test 3, here it is the obtained string before conversion string(42) "321002332003032333213033103001002003323021". It is the same than yours in Python. 
But after a base conversion from 4 to 10, here is the result "17241216183876080046824606".

Finally, I don't think it is useful to have big numbers in your clash because as said @5DN1L, all programming languages can NOT handle such large numbers.

You clash is interesting ! If you could reduce the length of the strings to convert so that  many languages can succeed your clash...

Constraints section
* Is there a better way to represent the upper limit of the maximal number, e.g. 10^200? I cannot even see the whole number with my window expanded to the widest.

Cases
* I'm not sure whether all programming languages can handle such large numbers as easily as Python. I suggest that the cases be adjusted so that players using other programming languages can actually have a chance to win the clash (in case the large numbers are an issue).

Thanks.
Fixed. Now, max number is 4*10^15.
Thank you for your comment ! I understand your point of view. I've reduced the outputs. Also, validators are now always smaller than tests to avoid bad surprises... Could you please test new inputs ?
Thank you ! :)
Thanks! :)
Thank you.

It works better ... until the last test because in PHP, using the function str_replace(), it will replace the first time 3 by 9 and then replace it again 9 by E... The only way to succeed the last test is by using the preg_replace() function which use regex pattern, or by checking if a value is a key in the array and by making a tricky replacement, like the value for the key 9  becomes '&&' and with the final string, replace '&&' by 'E . So, it becomes really fastidious... even more if there an input string with '&&' in it...

That's why I'm using a dictionary to assign a new character for each character ;)

Else, I've changed the last test. Now it's in base 18. Can you solve it, outputs are bigger...

My method:
1. put each unique character in a list with reverse order of appearance,
2. when the list is complete, create a dictionary assigning for each character of the list a character from the list : 0 to 9, A to Z (0123456789ABCDEFGHIJ....),
3. create a new string by replacing each character of [[s]] by the corresponding one in the dictionary,
4. translate to base 10.

Yep, I understood your method in Python but for some languages, dictionnary does not exist. We only have arrays. Anyway, it won't change anything.
It is just the replacement that will be tricky. 
For example, in PHP, if you do something like that :

array{ ["A"]=>"4",["D"]=>"A" }

First, it will changes '4' by 'A' in the string and then 'A' by 'D' in the same string.

The replacement does not work in the same way between languages. If I understand well, in Python the replacement is done directly once in the string. While in PHP, the replacement is done one key after one.

In this language, to avoid this twice replacement, we do not have other solutions than using regex or make something tricky

In python, if we write : string.replace("4", "A").replace("A", "D") (which means replace all the "4" by "A", then replace all the "A" by "D"), we will have the exact same issue as you.
The idea is to create a NEW string (G in my code), not replacing characters in the string one by one...

OK ! Sorry ! I did not see this point (and thanks for the tip ;) )
Now, for the last test I have the same output string before conversion 'HGFEDCBA98765432110' but it seems too huge to convert .
The expected output is 705784704021928203429078 whereas I have 705784704021928262846840
Well done, this is the correct assignment, but the output seems definitely too huge for PHP... So, I will probably delete this last test.
And of course thank you for your testing ! :)
I've changed the last test, now you may be able to solve this puzzle with a 100% score. ;)
Thanks ! Funny the title for the last validator, but in base up to 36 it can works if the number to convert to base 10 is not huge

Well no, remember that I have to write all the characters of the base (in order that you detect that it is a base 36), so the minimum output will be 106300512100105327644605138221229898724869759421181854980
